datasets.name: data.csv
datasets.description: Related to science of cooking, food chemistry, and avant-garde cuisine.

columns.name: cooking_method
columns.description: Type of cooking method used

columns.name: cooking_technology_level
columns.description: Assessment of the level of technology used in cooking, high-tech or low-tech

columns.name: online_courses_count
columns.description: Number of online courses on molecular gastronomy available from institutions within the region

columns.name: number_of_cooking_techniques
columns.description: Count of distinct cooking techniques used in the preparation of the dish

columns.name: guest_preferences_variation
columns.description: Numerical rating from 1 to 5 indicating variation in guest preferences

columns.name: is_special_event
columns.description: Indicates whether the dish is prepared for a special culinary event

columns.name: ingredient_origin
columns.description: Country or region where the main ingredient originates

columns.name: presentation_novelty
columns.description: Quantifies the novelty of dish presentation on a scale

columns.name: culinary_patents_count
columns.description: Number of patents registered for culinary devices and technologies in the region

columns.name: local_competitions_presence
columns.description: Indicates whether there are any local molecular gastronomy competitions in the region

columns.name: cultural_significance
columns.description: Binary indicator of whether the ingredient is considered significant in any cultural cuisine (1 if yes, 0 if no)

columns.name: beverage_pairing
columns.description: Type of beverage, if any, that the dish is paired with

columns.name: celebrity_chef_presence
columns.description: Indicates whether a celebrity chef is involved in the molecular gastronomy offerings in the region

columns.name: culinary_technique_cost
columns.description: The cumulative cost associated with applying advanced culinary techniques to the main ingredient

columns.name: local_ingredient_usage
columns.description: Percentage of ingredients in the dish that are locally sourced

columns.name: special_equipment
columns.description: Indicates if the dish requires specialized culinary equipment

columns.name: microbial_population_optimal
columns.description: Boolean indicating if the microbial population in the soil is at an optimal level for ingredient growth.

columns.name: sensory_impact_score
columns.description: Scores the intended sensory impact of the dish, focusing on aroma, flavor intensity, and visual presentation

columns.name: seasonal_availability
columns.description: Binary indicator of whether the ingredient is seasonally available (1 if yes, 0 if no)

columns.name: soil_richness_level
columns.description: Numeric score representing the richness of the soil where the ingredient is grown, higher scores indicate richer soil.

columns.name: production_volume
columns.description: Annual production volume of the ingredient in metric tons

columns.name: culinary_technique_heat
columns.description: Represents the level of heat required, on a scale, for cooking techniques

columns.name: peak_ingredient_availability
columns.description: Boolean indicating whether the ingredient is at its peak availability in the local markets or not.

columns.name: customer_satisfaction_rating
columns.description: Average satisfaction rating for the dish on a scale from 1 to 10

columns.name: preparation_steps
columns.description: Counts the total number of steps required to prepare the dish

columns.name: predicted_satisfaction_increase
columns.description: The predicted increase in satisfaction

columns.name: media_exposures_count
columns.description: Number of times molecular gastronomy featured in media such as television or significant publications in a year

columns.name: chef_experience_level
columns.description: Experience level of the chef

queries.question: What is the relationship between the customer satisfaction rating and the predicted satisfaction increase in the dataset?
queries.true_hypothesis: The predicted satisfaction increase is calculated as the cube of the difference between the customer satisfaction rating and 1, divided by 729.
